STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 10, 2022
Jody Schlaufman
Otsego/Crawford/Oscoda DHHS
931 S. Otsego Ave
Gaylord, MI 49735
RE: License #: CP690201347
Otsego/Crawford/Oscoda DHHS
931 S. Otsego Ave
Gaylord, MI 49735
Dear Ms. Schlaufman:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
August 8, 2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Kari Muntean, Area Manager, at 734-395-0920.
Sincerely,
Doug Turrill, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 11
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City, MI 49684
(734) 395-0920
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP690201347
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling, Administrator
Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Otsego/Crawford/Oscoda DHHS
Facility Address: 931 S. Otsego Ave
Gaylord, MI 49735
Facility Telephone #: (989) 732-1702

SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement.
(3) An agency shall document review of the foster
parent/agency agreement with the foster family at least
annually and, when needed, develop a new agreement.
One of three files reviewed did not contain an updated parent/agency agreement.
The Licensing Supervisor provided a signed copy of the agreement however it was
not uploaded into the MISACWIS system at the time of the review.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
One of three files reviewed did not document written endorsement of the initial
evaluation.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is
acceptable.
One of three files reviewed did not document written endorsement of the
reevaluation.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
4

Two of ten files reviewed each contained a USP that was late. In one file the USP
was due on May 8, 2022, and the report was completed on May 11, 2022. A second
file contained a USP that was due on December 8, 2021, and the report was
completed on December 10, 2021.
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
Three of three independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation that
the youth received a copy of the agency independent living program.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency's policies and procedures required by this
rule.
Three of three independent living files reviewed did not contain documentation that
the youth received a copy of the agency independent living policies and procedures.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between the
youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
Two of three independent living files did not contain documentation of a contract
between the youth and the agency. A third file contained a contract dated
September 27, 2021, however, there was not updated contracts since that time.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
5

Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Second line supervisor, when
siblings in care are placed apart. • Parents who are a
member of a participating household. • Youth ages 14 and
older. • Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
Six of ten files reviewed each contained a PATP that was not signed or was signed
late. One of the files contained a USP dated May 17, 2022, that did not have
signatures. A second file contained a USP dated January 24, 2022, that did not
contain signatures. A third file contained a USP dated May 11, 2022, that
documented signatures, however, the signatures were late, signed July 14, 2022. A
fourth file contained a USP dated May 8, 2022, that was not signed by the youth. A
fifth file contained a USP dated April 14, 2022, that did not document signatures. A
sixth file contained a USP dated March 4, 2022, that was not signed by the foster
parent until May 9, 2022.
FOM 722-16 DHHS-1295, Young Adult Monthly Visit Report
The DHHS-1295, Young Adult Monthly Visit Report, must be
completed with the youth during each home visit. A copy
must be uploaded into MISACWIS a copy must be given to
the youth.
One of one YAVFC files reviewed did not document that the DHHS -1295 form was
being used for visitations. Monthly visitations were occurring, however, the last
completed DHHS-1295 form was dated September 1, 2021.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following: Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date. Note: This
FTM may be combined with the CPS Case Opening (ISP)
FTM. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date. Permanent Ward Service Plan
(PWSP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan due
date.
Following the FTM, the caseworker is responsible for the
following:  Completing the DHHS-1105, Family Team
Meeting Report, checking it for accuracy, identifying areas
needing follow-up, and recording the outcome data.  The
caseworker must enter the FTM information (DHHS-1105) in
MISACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven business
days of the FTM.
6

Two of ten files reviewed each contained a service plan period where an FTM was
not held. In one file there was no FTM for a USP dated May 9, 2022. A second file
documented that the last FTM was held on September 15, 2021. A third file
documented that the FTM occurred for a March 3, 2022, USP, however the DHHS-
1105 was not in the file.
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts
The caseworker must meet with their supervisor at least
monthly for case consultation on every assigned case.
Monthly case consultation may be conducted in person or
by video conference.
One of ten files reviewed did not document that supervision between the worker and
the supervisor occurred for the month February 2022.
FOM 801-03 Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
One of ten files reviewed contained a gap between updated medical passports. An
updated medical passport was completed on August 6, 2021, and the next updated
passport was completed on June 6, 2022. There was a gap of 10 months where
passports were not updated.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Technical assistance was provided regarding youth with YAVFC status who are
placed in an independent living placement. Discussion involved when YAFC youth
are in an independent living arrangement, such as a college dorm or an apartment,
then that youth is considered to be in independent living and the independent living
rules apply. The independent living rules do not apply to YAFC youth living with a
relative, in a foster home, or a CCI.
V. CONSULTATION
Consultation was not requested or offered at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
7

this licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
A corrective action plan, approved September 27, 2021, was submitted in response
to the Interim Inspection completed on August 19, 2021. There were no repeat
violations established during the current renewal Inspection. The agency continues
to successfully address and correct rule and policy violations established during the
previous annual inspection. There were no complaints against the agency during the
licensing period, therefore no special investigations were initiated.
Chief Administrators Annual Assessment: (CAA)
The Chief Administrators annual assessment identified that the agency has added a
program manager position to the agency which has provided additional support for
the tri-county agency. The assessment also details how the agency has
implemented a Team Decision Making model in the past year which provides for
increased inclusion of parents, children, and community members in the decision
making and treatment process. The assessment also describes how the agency
utilizes the Child Welfare Dashboard to monitor data input.
The Chief Administrator Assessment further reports that the agency experienced
significant staffing transitions during the year however a cohesive team is now in
place and operating well. Children and family members with mental health problems
continue to be a challenge for the agency and sometimes result in disrupted
placements. In conclusion, the annual assessment thoroughly addresses areas of
needed correction.
Interviews:
Staff interviewed reported feeling supported by their supervisors and the
administrative team and they feel that they are part of a supportive team. Staff also
reported that their supervisors are knowledgeable and are readily available when
they seek supervision. One staff reported that her supervisor is a good leader and
teacher, who has helped her to learn the requirements of her position.
Field Analyst Findings:
On June 22, 2022, during a visit to a foster home the Field Analyst identified a safety
concern as a bathroom being remodeled which resulted in having no sink and
unfinished flooring at the time of the visit. The agency was notified and they initiated
a special evaluation as they were unaware that the bathroom was being remodeled.
The agency completed the evaluation and found the foster home to be in non-
compliance with R 400.9305. The agency implemented a corrective action plan and
a safety plan until construction was completed. A variance was also submitted to
DCWL.
8

The Field Analyst also reported during the entrance conference that foster families
and relatives were generally positive about the services they received from the
agency and there were no major concerns reported.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
August 10, 2022
________________________________________
Doug Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 10, 2022
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Area Manager
